sections.content: Python is the most beginner-friendly programming language and one of the most powerful. It's used by Google, Netflix, NASA, and millions of developers worldwide. Whether you want to automate tasks, analyze data, build websites, or create AI applications, Python is your gateway. Best part: You don't need computer science degree. You just need curiosity and practice.

sections.title: Why Python Dominates
items: Readable: Syntax reads almost like English
Versatile: Web development, data science, automation, AI, more
Beginner-friendly: Easiest language to learn
Powerful: Professional-grade capabilities
In-demand: Top 3 most wanted programming skills
Community: Massive support, libraries, resources
Career: Opens doors to high-paying tech roles

sections.content: The career advantage: Python developers earn $95K-$150K+ average salary. Skills are transferable across industries. Even basic Python knowledge dramatically increases your value. Automation alone can save hours daily. Data analysis skills transform decision-making. This isn't just learning to code—it's learning to create leverage.

sections.title: What You Can Build with Python
items: Automation: Scripts that do repetitive tasks for you
Data analysis: Extract insights from data
Web scraping: Gather information from websites
Web applications: Full websites and web apps
APIs: Connect different services and tools
Machine learning: AI and predictive models
Games: Simple to complex game development
Desktop applications: Full software programs

sections.title: Learning Path Overview
items: Module 1: Python Basics - Variables, data types, basic operations
Module 2: Control Structures - Logic, loops, functions
Module 3: Data Structures - Lists, dictionaries, file handling
Module 4: Projects - Real applications you'll build
Timeline: 4-8 weeks to basic proficiency with daily practice
Reality: Programming is learned by doing, not just reading

sections.content: The 20-hour rule: Studies show you can go from knowing nothing to basic competence in about 20 hours of focused practice. That's less than an hour daily for a month. You won't be expert, but you'll be functional. Most people never start because they think it requires years. It doesn't.

sections.title: Getting Started
items: Install Python: Download from python.org (latest version)
Code editor: VS Code (free, popular) or PyCharm Community
Online option: repl.it or Google Colab (code in browser)
Practice platforms: HackerRank, LeetCode, Codewars
Documentation: python.org/docs (official reference)
Community: Reddit r/learnpython, Stack Overflow
Start simple: Don't worry about perfect setup, just start coding

quiz.question: What makes Python beginner-friendly?
options: Readable syntax that looks like English, simple to learn yet powerful
quiz.explanation: Python is beginner-friendly because syntax reads almost like English, it's simple to learn, yet powerful enough for professional applications.

quiz.question: How long to basic competence?
options: About 20 hours of focused practice (less than 1 hour daily for a month)
quiz.explanation: 20-hour rule: About 20 hours of focused practice gets you from nothing to basic competence. That's less than an hour daily for a month.

sections.content: Variables are containers that store information. Think of them as labeled boxes where you put data. Data types determine what kind of information you can store. Understanding these fundamentals is foundation of all programming. Master this, everything else becomes easier.

sections.title: Creating Variables
items: Syntax: variable_name = value
Example: age = 25 (stores number 25 in variable called age)
Example: name = 'John' (stores text 'John' in variable called name)
Rules: Start with letter or underscore, no spaces, case-sensitive
Convention: Use lowercase with underscores (snake_case)
Good: user_age, total_price, is_active
Bad: UserAge, totalprice, 1user (starts with number)

sections.content:
Code example:

```python
name = 'Alice'
age = 30
height = 5.6
is_student = True

print(name)  # Output: Alice
print(age)   # Output: 30
```

The equals sign (=) is assignment operator. It stores value on right into variable on left.

sections.title: Core Data Types
items: int: Whole numbers (age = 25, count = 100, year = 2024)
float: Decimal numbers (price = 19.99, height = 5.8)
str: Text strings (name = 'John', message = 'Hello')
bool: True or False (is_active = True, has_access = False)
None: Represents absence of value (result = None)
Checking type: type(variable_name) shows data type

sections.title: Working with Strings
items: Creating: Single quotes 'text' or double quotes "text"
Concatenation: 'Hello' + ' ' + 'World' = 'Hello World'
Length: len('Hello') returns 5
Uppercase: 'hello'.upper() returns 'HELLO'
Lowercase: 'HELLO'.lower() returns 'hello'
Replace: 'Hello'.replace('H', 'J') returns 'Jello'
F-strings: f'My age is {age}' embeds variables in strings

sections.content:
String examples:

```python
first_name = 'John'
last_name = 'Doe'

# Concatenation
full_name = first_name + ' ' + last_name
print(full_name)  # Output: John Doe

# F-strings (modern, preferred)
greeting = f'Hello, {full_name}!'
print(greeting)  # Output: Hello, John Doe!
```

sections.title: Basic Operations
items: Addition: 5 + 3 = 8
Subtraction: 10 - 4 = 6
Multiplication: 6 * 7 = 42
Division: 15 / 3 = 5.0 (always returns float)
Integer division: 15 // 3 = 5 (returns int)
Modulo: 17 % 5 = 2 (remainder after division)
Exponent: 2 ** 3 = 8 (2 to the power of 3)

sections.title: Type Conversion
items: To integer: int('25') converts string to 25
To float: float('19.99') converts string to 19.99
To string: str(25) converts number to '25'
To boolean: bool(1) = True, bool(0) = False
Use case: Converting user input (always string) to number
Example: age = int(input('Enter age: '))

quiz.question: What's correct variable naming?
quiz.explanation: Correct: user_age. Variables start with letter/underscore, no spaces, use snake_case convention (lowercase with underscores).

quiz.question: What does len('Hello') return?
quiz.explanation: len('Hello') returns 5 - the number of characters in the string. len() function returns length as integer.

sections.content: Programs need to communicate: receive information (input) and display results (output). Input gets data from users. Output shows results. These are fundamental to interactive programs. Every calculator, game, or app uses input/output constantly.

sections.title: The print() Function
items: Basic: print('Hello') displays: Hello
Variables: print(age) displays value of age variable
Multiple: print('Age:', age) displays: Age: 25
Separator: print('a', 'b', 'c', sep='-') displays: a-b-c

New line: print('Line 1
Line 2') shows on separate lines
No newline: print('Text', end='') doesn't add line break
F-string: print(f'I am {age} years old') embeds variables

sections.content:
Print examples:

```python
name = 'Alice'
age = 28

print('Name:', name)  # Output: Name: Alice
print('Age:', age)    # Output: Age: 28
print(f'{name} is {age} years old')  # Output: Alice is 28 years old
```

sections.title: The input() Function
items: Syntax: variable = input('Prompt message')
Always returns string: Need to convert for numbers
Example: name = input('Enter your name: ')
Number input: age = int(input('Enter age: '))
Float input: price = float(input('Enter price: '))
Process: Displays prompt, waits for user, returns entered text

sections.content:
Input example:

```python
# Get user information
name = input('What is your name? ')
age = int(input('How old are you? '))

# Calculate birth year
current_year = 2024
birth_year = current_year - age

# Display result
print(f'Hello {name}! You were born around {birth_year}.')
```

sections.title: Formatting Output
items: F-strings (preferred): f'Value: {variable}'
Decimal places: f'Price: {price:.2f}' shows 2 decimals
Alignment: f'{text:>10}' right-aligns in 10 spaces
Thousands separator: f'{1000000:,}' displays 1,000,000
Percentage: f'{0.15:.1%}' displays 15.0%
Example: f'Total: ${price:.2f}' for money

sections.title: Building Interactive Programs
items: 1. Prompt for input: Ask clear questions
2. Get user response: Use input() function
3. Convert if needed: Turn strings to numbers
4. Process data: Perform calculations or logic
5. Display results: Show formatted output
6. Validate: Check input makes sense (covered later)
Pattern: Input → Process → Output (IPO model)

sections.content:
Complete example - Simple calculator:

```python
print('=== Simple Calculator ===')

num1 = float(input('Enter first number: '))
num2 = float(input('Enter second number: '))

sum_result = num1 + num2
diff = num1 - num2
product = num1 * num2

print(f'
Sum: {sum_result}')
print(f'Difference: {diff}')
print(f'Product: {product}')
```

quiz.question: What does input() always return?
options: String (text) - must convert to numbers if needed
quiz.explanation: input() always returns string. Must convert to int or float for numeric operations: age = int(input('Age: '))

quiz.question: What's f'Price: {price:.2f}' do?
options: Displays price with exactly 2 decimal places
quiz.explanation: :.2f formats number with 2 decimal places. Useful for displaying money: $19.99 instead of $19.989999.

sections.content: Operators are symbols that perform operations on values. Expressions combine values and operators to produce results. These are building blocks of logic and calculations in programming. Every calculation, comparison, and decision uses operators.

sections.title: Arithmetic Operators
items: + Addition: 5 + 3 = 8
- Subtraction: 10 - 4 = 6
* Multiplication: 6 * 7 = 42
/ Division: 15 / 3 = 5.0
// Floor division: 15 // 4 = 3 (rounds down)
% Modulo: 17 % 5 = 2 (remainder)
** Exponentiation: 2 ** 3 = 8 (2³)

sections.content:
Order of operations (PEMDAS):

```python
result = 2 + 3 * 4  # = 14 (multiplication first)
result = (2 + 3) * 4  # = 20 (parentheses first)

# Use parentheses for clarity
total = (price * quantity) + tax
average = (num1 + num2 + num3) / 3
```

sections.title: Comparison Operators
items: == Equal to: 5 == 5 is True
!= Not equal: 5 != 3 is True
> Greater than: 10 > 5 is True
< Less than: 3 < 10 is True
>= Greater or equal: 5 >= 5 is True
<= Less or equal: 3 <= 5 is True
Result: Always True or False (boolean)

sections.title: Logical Operators
items: and: Both must be True (True and True = True)
or: At least one must be True (True or False = True)
not: Inverts boolean (not True = False)
Example: age >= 18 and has_license
Example: is_weekend or is_holiday
Example: not is_closed
Use: Combine multiple conditions

sections.content:
Logical operator examples:

```python
age = 25
has_license = True

# Both conditions must be True
can_drive = age >= 18 and has_license
print(can_drive)  # True

# At least one must be True
is_free_day = is_weekend or is_holiday

# Invert boolean
is_open = not is_closed
```

sections.title: Assignment Operators
items: = Assign: x = 5
+= Add and assign: x += 3 (same as x = x + 3)
-= Subtract and assign: x -= 2 (same as x = x - 2)
*= Multiply and assign: x *= 4 (same as x = x * 4)
/= Divide and assign: x /= 2 (same as x = x / 2)
Shorthand: Cleaner code for updating variables

sections.title: Membership & Identity
items: in: Checks if value in sequence ('a' in 'apple' = True)
not in: Checks if value not in sequence
is: Checks if same object (x is None)
is not: Checks if different object (x is not None)
Use 'in': For checking substring or list membership
Use 'is': For comparing to None, True, False

sections.content:
Practical example - Discount calculator:

```python
price = float(input('Enter price: $'))
quantity = int(input('Enter quantity: '))

subtotal = price * quantity

# Apply discount if buying 10 or more
if quantity >= 10:
    discount = subtotal * 0.10
    total = subtotal - discount
    print(f'10% discount applied: ${discount:.2f}')
else:
    total = subtotal

print(f'Total: ${total:.2f}')
```

quiz.question: What does 17 % 5 return?
quiz.explanation: % (modulo) returns remainder after division. 17 ÷ 5 = 3 remainder 2, so 17 % 5 = 2.

quiz.question: What does 'and' operator require?
quiz.explanation: 'and' requires BOTH conditions True. True and True = True. True and False = False. Use for multiple requirements.

sections.content: Writing code is communication: with the computer AND with humans (including future you). Good code is readable, well-organized, and documented. These practices separate beginners from professionals. Learning them early saves countless hours later.

sections.title: Comments
items: Single line: # This is a comment
Purpose: Explain WHY, not WHAT (code shows what)
Good: # Calculate compound interest over 10 years
Bad: # Add 1 to x (obvious from code)
Multi-line: Triple quotes for longer explanations
Docstrings: '''Function description''' at function start
Balance: Comment complex logic, not every line

sections.content:
Comment examples:

```python
# Good: Explains reasoning
# Using 365.25 to account for leap years
days_in_year = 365.25

# Bad: States obvious
# Set age to 25
age = 25

# Good: Documents complex logic
# Apply progressive tax brackets
if income <= 10000:
    tax = income * 0.10
else:
    tax = 1000 + (income - 10000) * 0.20
```

sections.title: Naming Conventions
items: Variables: snake_case (user_age, total_price)
Constants: UPPER_CASE (MAX_SIZE, PI)
Descriptive: total_revenue not tr
Avoid: Single letters except loops (i, j, k acceptable)
Boolean: Use is_, has_, can_ prefix (is_valid, has_access)
Consistency: Pick convention and stick to it
Clarity: Code read 10x more than written, optimize for reading

sections.title: Code Organization
items: Blank lines: Separate logical sections
Spacing: Spaces around operators (x = 5, not x=5)
Line length: Keep under 80 characters when possible
Grouping: Related code stays together
Imports: At top of file
Structure: Input → Processing → Output
Readability: If it looks messy, it probably is

sections.title: The DRY Principle
items: DRY: Don't Repeat Yourself
Problem: Same code in multiple places
Solution: Use functions, loops, variables
Bad: Copying same calculation 5 times
Good: Calculate once, store in variable, use multiple times
Why: Easier to maintain, fewer bugs, cleaner code
Later: Functions make this even more powerful

sections.content:
Clean code example:

```python
# Investment Calculator
# Calculates future value with compound interest

# Constants
YEARS = 10
INTEREST_RATE = 0.07  # 7% annual return

# Get user input
initial_investment = float(input('Initial investment: $'))

# Calculate future value
# Formula: FV = PV × (1 + r)^n
future_value = initial_investment * (1 + INTEREST_RATE) ** YEARS

# Display results
profit = future_value - initial_investment
print(f'
After {YEARS} years:')
print(f'Future value: ${future_value:,.2f}')
print(f'Profit: ${profit:,.2f}')
```

sections.title: Debugging Tips
items: Print statements: Add print() to see variable values
Check types: print(type(variable)) shows data type
Test small: Break problem into smaller pieces
Read errors: Error messages tell you what's wrong
Google errors: Copy error message, search online
Comment out: Temporarily disable code to isolate problem
Take breaks: Fresh eyes find bugs faster

quiz.question: What should comments explain?
quiz.explanation: Comments explain WHY, not WHAT. Code shows what it does; comments explain reasoning, complex logic, and decisions.

quiz.question: What's DRY principle?
options: Don't Repeat Yourself - avoid duplicating same code
quiz.explanation: DRY: Don't Repeat Yourself. If you copy-paste code, you should probably use functions, loops, or variables instead.
